journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Ultra-precision grinding of asymmetric curved surfaces by line contact with cup wheel

article-meta.aff: Key Laboratory for Precision and Non-Traditional Machining Technology of Ministry of Education, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian, China

author-notes.corresp: FW Huo, Key Laboratory for Precision and Non-Traditional Machining Technology of Ministry of Education, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, China. Email: huofw@dlut.edu.cn

abstract.p: The wheel wear is a crucial factor affecting the shape accuracy while grinding the asymmetric curved surface components. To decrease the effects of the wheel wear and improve the machining accuracy, a novel approach of grinding with large-size and fine-grained cup wheel was suggested. This method has many advantages: a full line contact of the cup wheel against the work-piece can be realized, the wheel shape can be well maintained, and the wheel wear is uniform and can be compensated just by feeding along its axis. Moreover, a mathematical model was developed to analyze the grinding motion and the grinding principle deviation. Two hydrodynamic seal rings with wavy surfaces used in reactor coolant pumps were taken as examples to verify the practicability. It is expected to be an efficient method to manufacture more complex asymmetric curved surfaces with high shape accuracy and high surface quality.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the development of science and technology, complex surface components have a wide application and increasing proportion in machinery, electronics, medical science, and aerospace.1–3 Among them, high precision asymmetric curved surface components play an irreplaceable role due to their special functions. They are usually made of hard and brittle ceramic materials, such as alumina, silicon nitride, and silicon carbide, and have excellent mechanical, thermal properties, and chemical stability.4,5 However, on account of their high hardness and brittleness, it is difficult for the cutting tool to penetrate the work-piece and it is prone to generate chipping and cracking. Among different methods that have been developed to fabricate these complex surface components,6,7 grinding is an important and feasible mechanical machining method applied as the main approach to form work-pieces with low surface roughness, high shape accuracy, and high surface integrity. Especially, ultra-precision grinding, being the finish process, is aiming at generating products with ultimate machining precision.8

Conventionally, multi-axis computer numerical control grinding with V-shaped, cup, torus-shaped or hemisphere wheel is used for asymmetric curved surface formation.9 A V-shaped wheel is used in point-to-point grinding method whose contact area is limited; usually, it is adopted to grind small-size work-piece with a large curvature. Venkatesh et al.10 proposed an application of keeping the contact points of the cup wheel grinding fixed to generate the asymmetric curved surface in zone-by-zone method where the feature of the grinding surface is axisymmetric. To improve the material removal rate and end up with the desired surface shape, the contact area between the grinding wheel and the work-piece should be as large as possible; on the other hand, the wheel shape should be constant during the grinding process. Kuriyagawa et al.11 developed an arc envelope grinding method for the asymmetric curved surface using a torus-shaped wheel with a curved profile. In the arc envelope grinding method, the work-piece profile is generated by a series of envelope arcs; as the contact point is changed along the wheel profile, multiple points of the wheel in the direction of the width can be effectively used and the wheel life is, therefore, prolonged. Shore et al.12 suggested to grind with the Big OptiX system using an inclined toroidal shaped diamond wheel that could achieve a peak-to-valley value of 1 µm on a 1 m part and the subsurface damage in the range 2–5 µm; the cutting region and peripheral contact zone are changed to maintain the machining stability and keep the wheel shape. Hwang et al.13 adopted a tilted hemisphere wheel to grind the aspheric surface using parallel grinding method, and the variation of functional area on the wheel surface insures that the wear is evenly distributed along the wheel surface. However, no matter which type of the grinding wheel is used, the non-uniform wear of the wheel profile is a common problem. Furthermore, when grinding the hard and brittle material parts, a series of damage exists, such as deformed layer, surface/subsurface micro-crack, phase transformation, and residual stresses, which will degrade the strength and must be removed by an additional polishing process.14 To improve the grinding quality, the wheel should be dressed frequently. One of the problems induced is that if the grinding wheel designed for point contact grinding has a complex profile, the work-piece shape accuracy will be badly affected as a result of the rapid wheel wear and the wheel dressing and the precision measurement and tool setting are all difficult to be carried out. Therefore, the wheel used in ultra-precision grinding should take simple shape and easy dressing as selection criteria.

The combination of the three key elements including the complex surface, hard and brittle material, and high shape accuracy demand is a great challenge to the ultra-precision grinding technology.13 At present, large-size and fine-grained cup wheel is mainly adopted to grind silicon wafers used for semiconductor manufacturing, and submicron global flatness and angstrom surface roughness have been achieved.15–19 This article proposed a new method for grinding asymmetric curved surfaces by line contact with large-size and fine-grained cup wheel. Two hydrodynamic seal rings with asymmetric curved surfaces were taken as examples to verify the practicability of line contact grinding using this type of cup wheel. Analysis about the grinding principle error shows that this method is a feasible way for many complex surface component formation.

sec.title: Mathematical model for asymmetric curved surface generation
sec.p:
The structural illustration of the grinding machine is shown in Figure 1. It has two linear and two rotary axes. The cup wheel is mounted on the top surface of the rotary table B horizontally and the work-piece is held on the front surface of the spindle C. The feed motions are achieved by linear axes X and Z. Figure 1.
Structural illustration of the grinding machine model.

Five-coordinate systems are adopted to analyze the kinetic relations, as shown in Figure 2. The circle (α = 0) represents the original position of the cup wheel. There is a grinding contact arc between the grinding wheel and the work-piece with the start point being P1 and end point P2. The origin O4 of the O4–X4Y4Z4 coordinate system is the center of the cup wheel. The Z4-axis and the wheel axis are in the same line. The Y4-axis passes through the characteristic point P0 of the cutting circle. O2–X3Y3Z3 coordinate system is acquired by translating h from O4–X4Y4Z4 coordinate system. The O2–X2Y2Z2 coordinate system is acquired by rotating an angle α from the O2–X3Y3Z3 coordinate system around the rotary table B. Arbitrary machining position of the cup wheel is shown as the circle (α ≠ 0). The work-piece coordinate system which rotates around the C-axis is defined as the O–X1Y1Z1 coordinate system. The basic coordinate system of the machine tool is defined as O–XYZ. The translation distances from the O2–X2Y2Z2 coordinate system to the basic coordinate system in the three coordinate directions are denoted as l, m, and n. The phase angle of point P1 relative to P0 is ϕ1 and that of P2 ϕ2; P1P2 is the grinding contact arc. Figure 2.
Coordinate systems of grinding the asymmetric curved surfaces.

To analyze whether the surface could be machined by this method, an arbitrary point on the work-piece is chosen for mathematical derivation. In the O4–X4Y4Z4 coordinate system, the coordinate of an arbitrary point P in the contact arc is (1)[x4y4z4]=[RWsinφ-RWcosφ0] where RW is a radius of the cup wheel and ϕ the phase angle of point P shown as ∠PO1P0 and −π ≤ ϕ ≤ π.
The coordinates of point P in the coordinate system O2–X3Y3Z3 are (2)[x3y3z3]=[RWsinφ-RWcosφh]

Referring to the slope of the radial profile, rotary table B rotates an angle α. The coordinates of point P in the coordinate system O2–X2Y2Z2 are (3)[x2y2z2]=[cosα0sinα010-sinα0cosα]·[x3y3z3]=[RWcosαsinφ+hsinα-RWcosφ-RWsinαsinφ+hcosα]
The grinding point coordinate relative to the work-piece coordinate system is expressed as (4)[x1y1z1]=[x2y2z2]+[lmn]=[RWcosαsinφ+hsinα+l-RWcosφ+m-RWsinαsinφ+hcosα+n]

In the OX1Y1 plane, equations of the inner and outer circles are (5)x12+y12=R32 (6)x12+y12=R22 where R2 and R3 are the inner and outer radii of the work-piece, respectively. At the start point P1, RW, l, m, h, R3, α, and ϕ satisfy {x1=RWcosαsinφ+hsinα+ly1=-RWcosφ+mx12+y12=R32.
Above equations can be simplified into (7)(RWcosαsinφ+hsinα+l)2+(-RWcosφ+m)2=R32
When RW, l, m, n, h, α, and R3 are given, the exact solution of ϕ can be acquired by solving equation (7). It is obvious that ϕ1 is a function of RW, l, m, n, h, α, and R3 (8)φ1=φ(RW,l,m,n,h,α,R3)
Similarly, at the end point P2, we have {x1=RWcosαsinφ+hsinα+ly1=-RWcosφ+mx12+y12=R22.
Define the phase angle of the end point as ϕ2, which is a function associated with RW, l, m, n, h, α, and R2 and can be written as (9)φ2=φ(RW,l,m,n,h,α,R2)
When RW, l, m, n, h, α, and R2 are given, the contact arc location of the cup wheel with the work-piece can be determined in O–X1Y1Z1. So, the range of ϕ in equation (4) is ϕ1 ≤ ϕ ≤ ϕ2.

In the work-piece coordinate system, instantaneous contact arc of the cup wheel and the work-piece is a function of the phase angle θ. The parameter equations of the contact arc are (10)[xyz]=[cosθ-sinθ0sinθcosθ0001]·[x1y1z1] where −π ≤ θ ≤ π and ϕ1 ≤ ϕ ≤ ϕ2.

Regarding θ and ϕ as independent variables, the geometrical representation determined by equation (10) is a three-spatial surface. Equation (10) could be rewritten in parametric form as (11){x=u(RW,l,m,n,h,α,R3,R2,θ,φ)y=v(RW,l,m,n,h,α,R3,R2,θ,φ)z=w(RW,l,m,n,h,α,R3,R2,θ,φ) where −π ≤ θ ≤ π and ϕ1 ≤ ϕ ≤ ϕ2.

Equation (11) is the general expression of the generated surface. Among the eight parameters, R2 and R3 are work-piece related while the others to the machine configuration. For an annular work-piece with given R2 and R3, if all other variables are constant, a flat surface or an axisymmetric curved surface can be generated; if n is varied following a defined rule and α and other variables are constant, an asymmetric curved surface with identical radial profile shape can be machined; whereas, if α and n are both varied following defined rules, more complex asymmetric curved surfaces can be obtained.

sec.title: Typical applications
sec.p: It has been widely accepted that hydrodynamic effect exists between two relative sliding mechanical seal faces contoured with complex surface according to fluid dynamic lubrication theory. Hydrodynamic mechanical seals with complex curved surfaces, such as equal- and unequal-tilt wavy surfaces can be used in harsh environment such as high temperature, high pressure, frequent starts and stops, corrosive medium, and mixture slurry. Lebeck20,21 and Young and Lebeck22,23 had done many researches on the effects of wavy surface on the mechanical sealing performance. Not only the hydrodynamic effect but also the hydrostatic one will be generated by the equal- and unequal-tilt wavy surface seal rings. When the shaft rotates, the circumferential waviness provides hydrodynamic load support; the radial taper provides hydrostatic load support; and the seal dam restricts leakage.24 Recently, they have been successfully used in reactor coolant pumps, steam turbines, pipeline pumps, boiler circulation pumps, boiler feed pumps, and high-temperature pumps in refinery and hydrocarbon facilities.25,26 Generally, the maximum amplitude of these seal rings is just about 10 µm to limit leakage. The hydrodynamic seal rings used in a reactor coolant pump reach 300 mm in diameter and they are manufactured of silicon carbides, silicon nitride, or other hard and brittle ceramic materials. The required machining precision of roughness is restricted to nanometer scale and the peak-to-valley value is restricted to a submicron one. It was found that the proposed grinding method can be used to manufacture the seal rings with the equal- and unequal-tilt wavy surfaces.

sec.title: Grinding of the equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring
sec.p:
The end face of the equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring includes a flat dam surface and an equal-tilt wavy surface, as shown in Figure 3. A dramatic characteristic of this type of seal ring is that the radial profile of the equal-tilt wavy surface is a straight line section with a constant slope. The seal ring coordinate system is shown in Figure 4. Taking the dam surface as the OXY plane the Z- and seal ring axes are in the same line. One center of the smaller circles is located in the X-axis. R0 is defined as the average of the inner and outer radii of the work-piece. The radius of the larger circle is RL whose center is at point O2 and that of the smaller one is RS whose center is at point O1. The distance from the center of the smaller circle to the origin is denoted as a and that from the center of the larger one to the origin as b; γ0 is the slope of the radial profile of the equal-tilt wavy surface and N the number of waviness. To express the shape equation of the equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring, the following mathematical constants and functions are defined as R0=R2+R32δ1=πNb=acosδ1+(RS+RL)2-a2sin2δ1δ2=arccosa2RS+2a2RL+b2RS-RS(RL+RS)22a(a2RL+b2RS-RL2RS-RS2RL)(RL+RS)δ3=δ1-δ2f(x1,x2,x3)=x1cosx2+x32-x12sin2x2g(x1,x2,x3)=x1cos(x2-δ1)-x32-x12sin2(x2-δ1) Figure 3.
Shape of the equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring.
Figure 4.
Coordinate system of the equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring.

Calculation shows that the shape error is minimum if the middle diameter of the equal-tilt wavy surface is chosen to be a reference path of the wheel grinding motion. In the cylindrical coordinate system, the equation of the intersection curve of the equal-tilt wavy surface and the dam surface is (12){r=R0z={γ0(R2-f(a,RS,δ-2iδ1)),|δ-2iδ1|≤δ2γ0(R2-g(b,RL,δ-2iδ1)),|δ-2iδ1-δ1|≤δ3 where 0 ≤ δ ≤ 2π and i = 0, 1, 2, 3,…, 8.

The equation of the equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring is (13)z(δ)={γ0(r-f(a,RS,δ-2iδ1)),|δ-2iδ1|≤δ2, f(a,RS,δ-2iδ1)≤r≤R2γ0(r-g(b,RL,δ-2iδ1)),|δ-2iδ1-δ1|≤δ3, g(b,RL,δ-2iδ1)≤r≤R20, else where i = 0, 1, 2, 3,…, 8.

When ϕ = 0, the wheel circle intersects the middle circle of the equal-tilt wavy surface. Substituting ϕ = 0 into equation (10) results in the coordinates of point P0 as (14)[xyz]=[(hsinα+l)cosθ-(-RW+m)sinθ=R0cosθ(hsinα+l)sinθ+(-RW+m)cosθ=R0sinθhcosα+n]
Letting the z-coordinate of equation (12) and that of equation (14) be equal gives (15)hcosα+n={γ0(R2-f(a,RS,δ-2iδ1)),|δ-2iδ1|≤δ2γ0(R2-g(b,RL,δ-2iδ1)), |δ-2iδ1-δ1|≤δ3

No matter what value θ is set, l, m, and n satisfy equation (15). When θ = 0, l, m, and n can be solved as follows (16)hcosα+n={γ0(R2-f(a,RS,δ-2iδ1)),|δ-2iδ1|≤δ2γ0(R2-g(b,RL,δ-2iδ1)), |δ-2iδ1-δ1|≤δ3 where 0 ≤ δ ≤ 2π and i = 0, 1, 2, 3,…, 8.

As the slope of the equal-tilt wavy surface is a constant, the rotary table B will be locked in a determined position. There is a linkage between the two linear axes and the rotary C-axis; the cup wheel will grind the work-piece along the intersection curve between the equal-tilt wavy surface and the dam surface. When α = 0, the dam surface can be produced.

sec.title: Grinding of the unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring
sec.p:
The end face of the unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring includes a flat annular dam surface and an unequal-tilt wavy surface, as shown in Figure 5. A dramatic characteristic of this type seal ring is that the radial profile of the unequal-tilt wavy surface is a straight line section and the slope of the straight line section varies according to the phase angle periodically. The equation of the unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring is (17)(ϕ)={0if R1≤r<R3γ0(r-R3)(cos(Nϕ)-1)if R3≤r<R2 where R1 is the inner radius of the seal ring, R2 the outer radius of seal ring, R3 the inner radius of the wavy surface, γ0 the slope of the radial profile of the unequal-tilt wavy surface, N the number of waviness, and ϕ the phase angle. The equation of intersecting curve between the unequal-tilt wavy surface and middle diameter cylindrical surface is (18)[xyz]=[R0cosθR0sinθγ0(R0-R3)(cos(Nϕ)-1)] Figure 5.
Shape of the unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring.
At arbitrary moment, α should be equal to the slope of radial profile of the unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring. Hence, α=γ0(1-cos(Nϕ))
Letting equations (14) and (18) be equal to each other gives (19)[xyz]={(hsinα+l)cosθ-(-RW+m)sinθ=R0cosθ(hsinα+l)sinθ+(-RW+m)cosθ=R0sinθhcosα+n=γ0(R0-R3)(cos(Nϕ)-1) where R3 ≤ r ≤ R2.

When θ is set as an arbitrary value and l, m, n always satisfy equation (19). Therefore (20){l=R0-hsinαm=RWn=γ0(r-R3)(cos(Nϕ)-1)-hcosα where R3 ≤ r ≤ R2; l, m, and n are the instantaneous motion parameters of the machine tool when machining the unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring. The slope of the radial profile of the unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring is a variable. Therefore, the rotary table B must rotate a small angle around its axis to fit α. The linkage of the two linear and the two rotary axes insures that the work-piece is ground along the outer circle of the dam surface. When l, m, n, and α satisfy equation (20), the unequal-tilt wavy surface could be generated. When α = 0, the dam surface can be produced.

sec.title: Grinding principle error analyses and discussions
Grinding principle error analysis of the equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring
sec.p: The peak-to-valley value as one of the main evaluation indices represents the grinding principle error. It is obvious that the grinding principle error of the seal dam is zero, since the wheel end surface is parallel to the work-piece surface when α = 0. The coordinate of an arbitrary point in the seal ring surface can be marked as (x, y) whose phase angle is arctan (y/x); so, the equations of the ideal equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring can be written as (21)z={γ0(x2+y2-acos(arctan(yx)) -RS2-a2sin2(arctan(yx)))where |arctan(yx)-2iδ1|≤δ2, f(a,RS,δ-2iδ1) ≤x2+y2≤R2,i=0,1,2,3,…,8γ0(x2+y2-bcos(arctan(yx)-πN) +RL2-b2sin2(arctan(yx)-πN))where |arctan(yx)-2iδ1-δ1|≤δ3,g(b,RL,δ-2iδ1) ≤x2+y2≤R2,i=0,1,2,3,…,8

The equation of the generated equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring is given by parametric equations (22){x=u(RW,l,m,n,h,α,z(δ),θ,φ)y=v(RW,l,m,n,h,α,z(δ),θ,φ)z=w(RW,l,m,n,h,α,z(δ),θ,φ) where ϕ(RW, l, m, n, h, α, z(δ)) ≤ ϕ ≤ ϕ2.

The grinding principle deviation equation is (23){x=u(RW,m,n,l,h,α,z(δ),θ,φ)y=v(RW,m,n,l,h,α,z(δ),θ,φ)z={w(RW,m,n,l,h,α,z(δ),θ,φ) -γ0(x2+y2-acos(arctan(yx)) +RS2-a2sin2(arctan(yx)))where |arctan(yx)-2iδ1|≤δ2,f(a,RS,δ-2iδ1) ≤x2+y2≤R2,i=0,1,2,3,…,8w(RW,m,n,l,h,α,z(δ),θ,φ) -γ0(x2+y2-bcos(arctan(yx)-πN) +RL2-b2sin2(arctan(yx)-πN))where |arctan(yx)-2iδ1-δ1| ≤δ3,g(b,RL,δ-2iδ1) ≤x2+y2≤R2,i=0,1,2,3,…,8 where ϕ(RW, l, m, n, h, α, z(δ)) ≤ ϕ ≤ ϕ2.

An example is presented to show the grinding principle error of the equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring generated by the proposed grinding method. The diameter of the cup wheel is 350 mm. The seal ring parameters are: R1 = 138.5 mm, R2 = 152 mm, RL = 200 mm, RS = 41 mm, a = 110 mm, γ0 = 0.0011333 rad, and N = 9. The ideal shape of the equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring and the grinding principle deviation are shown in Figures 6 and 7, respectively. It is found that the maximum grinding principle error is only 0.064 µm. Figure 6.
Ideal shape of the equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring.
Figure 7.
Grinding principle deviation of the equal-tilt wavy surface seal ring.

sec.title: Grinding principle error analysis of unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring
sec.p: In the Z-axis direction, the equations of unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring can be written as (24)z=γ0(x2+y2-R3)(1-cos(Narctanyx)) where R32 ≤ x2 + y2 ≤ R22.
The equation of the generated seal ring can be given by the parametric equation (25){x=u(RW,l,m,n,h,α,z(ϕ),θ,φ)y=v(RW,l,m,n,h,α,z(ϕ),θ,φ)z=w(RW,l,m,n,h,α,z(ϕ),θ,φ) where ϕ1 ≤ ϕ ≤ ϕ2.

Grinding principle deviation equation is acquired by subtracting equation (24) from equation (25) (26){x=u(RW,l,m,n,h,α,z(ϕ),θ,φ)y=v(RW,l,m,n,h,α,z(ϕ),θ,φ)z=w(RW,l,m,n,h,α,z(ϕ),θ,φ) -γ0(x2+y2-R3)(1-cos(Narctanyx)) where ϕ1 ≤ ϕ ≤ ϕ2.

An example is presented to show the grinding principle error of the unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring generated by the proposed grinding method. The diameter of the cup wheel is 350 mm. The seal ring parameters are: R1 = 130 mm, R2 = 150 mm, R3 = 135 mm, γ0 = 0.0004 rad, and N = 9. The ideal shape of the unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring and the grinding principle deviation are shown in Figures 8 and 9, respectively. It is found that the maximum grinding principle error is only 0.116 µm. Figure 8.
Ideal shape of the unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring.
Figure 9.
Grinding principle deviation of the unequal-tilt wavy surface seal ring.

sec.title: Discussions
sec.p: Since the amplitude of the ground waviness is varied smoothly in a microscopic scale (e.g. the maximum amplitude of the mentioned seal rings is 12 µm), which means the width of the wheel teeth is small enough to be considered as a single line when compared with the curvature radius of the wavy surfaces, the non-uniform wear of cup wheel end surface affected by rotating α can be neglected.

Large-size diamond cup wheel is used for three purposes: insuring a full line contact with the work-piece surface, prolonging the wheel life, and decreasing the grinding principle error. As the wheel contact zone is larger, all the grits on the end surface of the cup wheel participate in grinding; this makes the wheel is further utilized. Therefore, the material removal rate of the line contact grinding is higher than that of the point contact grinding and the wheel life will be prolonged too. Taking further analyses, due to the existence of the cup wheel curvature, the grinding principle error is inevitable, but it can be decreased when a larger cup wheel is used.

To cover the whole surface being machined, it took about 2 h for a single scan of aspheric convex mirror of diameter 330 mm by the point contact grinding.27 But in this grinding method, as the cup wheel spindle is driven along the axial direction and its rotational speed is many times higher than that of the work-piece, the cup wheel just needs to take several tens or several hundreds of revolutions to finish one scan process. Meanwhile, micro-feed grinding can be achieved. The state of the art in motion accuracy produced by ultra-precision machine tools is in the order of nanometer.28,29 In this grinding principle, the depth of cut is the ratio of infeed rate to work-piece rotational speed; hence, a feed resolution of several nanometers can be guaranteed. That provides conditions for using the fine-grained diamond wheel which is one of the most important factors to achieve lower surface roughness.30 Kasuga et al.29 and Matsuo et al.31 reported that the surface roughness can be ameliorated using grinding wheels over 4000. When the 4000 wheel was used to grind polycrystalline silicon carbide and monocrystalline silicon carbide (4H-SiC), the root mean square height (Rq) values were 1.23 and 1.33 nm, respectively. The analyses and data above indicate that it is expected to manufacture complex asymmetric curved surfaces with high shape accuracy and high surface quality using fine-grained diamond wheel in the proposed grinding method.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A novel potential application of large-size and fine-grained cup wheel for the asymmetric curved surface machining was proposed. It uses two linear and two rotary axes. A mathematical model was developed to analyze the grinding motion and the grinding principle deviation. By changing the related variables in the parametric equation, which is used to express the shape of the ground work-piece, more complex surfaces can be obtained. This method has many advantages: a full line contact of the cup wheel against the work-piece can be realized; the wheel shape can be well maintained; and the wheel wear is uniform and can be compensated just by feeding along its axis. Two mechanical seal rings with wavy surface used in reactor coolant pumps were taken as examples to indicate the application feasibility of the proposed grinding method. It was found that the maximum grinding principle errors calculated were less than 0.12 µm.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study is supported by the National Basic Research Program of China (no. 2009CB724306) and the National Natural Science Foundation of China (no. 50875037).
